Master List

summary:
“The
Man Behind the Mask” 
Pt 4 
Peter
Parker x reader 
Warnings: Hospital, description of injured family member...
body:
“The Man Behind the Mask”

Pt 4

Peter Parker x reader

Warnings: Hospital, description of injured family member

Summary: You’ve recently moved to Queens, New York after your father finds a new job with the U.S. government handling alien affairs in the city. You’ve grown up in a small town, and it’s your junior year of high school; culture shock takes a whole new meaning when you’re saved by the famed new web-slinging Avenger - and when you meet a new group of friends at Midtown High that seem to always be hiding something. But things quickly get personal.

Masterlist / Pt 1 – Pt 2 – Pt 3

It was a blur of sounds and lights and faces. The black car your mother had taken to the school was a company car – a government car. With a driver. It all seemed so cold and official. Your mom was crying beside you in the backseat but unsuccessfully trying to hide it, for your sake. She tried to explain through her sobs what happened at your father’s workplace, but it seemed that she didn’t really know many details at all. Everything government-related was secretive, especially when it concerned alien affairs, and especially when the word ‘accident’ was thrown around. You were sure that they were keeping you and your mother in the dark about what happened – you’d bet money that they always knew more than they were saying.

The man in the suit and sunglasses behind the wheel never said a word and his facial expression never changed throughout the drive to the hospital. He seemed entirely uninviting. You noticed a bulge at his side underneath his suit jacket, and it didn’t take more than a moment to realize that it was a gun. Of course it was. What was he, security detail? To keep you and your mother safe or to maybe keep you two from probing more than you should be into the incident? Either way, you found his presence completely unnecessary and a bit unnerving.

Pulling up to the hospital, you threw open the SUV door before the vehicle was completely stopped and ran toward the doors despite your mother’s protests. The lobby was cold and sterile, bringing chill bumps to your arms. Your sense of foreboding only heightened.

“Baby, don’t go running off like that,” you heard your mother beg from behind you, resting her shaking hands on your shoulders. “I know that you want to see your dad, and—and that this is scary, but we’ve gotta stick together.”

You didn’t respond, watching as the large man that drove the SUV motion for you two to follow him down a nearby hallway. You followed his lead in a blur. The hospital wing was deserted, all the doors down the blindingly white hallway ajar, allowing you to peer into the rooms. Every bed was perfectly made, a fresh vase of flowers by every window. It was almost eerie.

“For security reasons,” came a deep voice through the haze. You looked into the dark sunglasses that looked back at you before they turned away. “No one underneath or above the floor our people are on. We don’t want anyone here that shouldn’t be, and it’s a hell of a lot easier to spot someone who doesn’t belong when no one should be in this hallway in the first place.”

“Surely – I mean, but patients were here, right?” you stuttered. “Where did they go?”

“Somewhere else,” he replied shortly, making it clear that the conversation was over. You glanced back at your mother, who shrugged and gave you a look that clearly said “stop asking questions”.

The three of you approached an elevator at the end of the off-putting corridor. There wasn’t an up or down button, but a keypad and a finger print scanner. Your brows furrowed. Why in the hell was this place like a disguised prison instead of a hospital? Who—or what—was your father being protected from? A shiver ran down your spine.

The large man obscured your view with his shoulder blades, leaning down to punch in a combination and scan his fingerprint. It was clear that you weren’t supposed to know how to get into this elevator without supervision. But this was your dad—he didn’t need protecting from you, from his family.

A loud alarm sounded throughout the hallway as the elevator arrived. You were sure that everyone in the hospital could hear it, and maybe that was the point—no surprise visitors. The blaring ceased as the doors opened and the three of you stepped inside. It was stainless steel and spotless, sterile, like everything else around you. You weren’t sure if this was comforting you, or the opposite. It was clean, but there was no warmth.

The elevator did not have any indicator or screen that told you what floor you were arriving to. You gulped as the doors finally parted for you, a hallway even more blindingly white meeting your vision, but this time it was full of people bustling around, all seemingly in a hurry. Nurses were in protective suits, masks covering their faces, as they entered a room at the very end of the hallway with a large caution indicator flashing above it. You couldn’t believe what you were seeing. It was like a scene from a science fiction movie.

“Your father isn’t in there,” a deep voice said, pulling you from your thoughts. Was that meant to be comforting? You looked up at his stony face, his lense-covered eyes betraying nothing. He simply motioned to his right, down a separate hallway. You followed the bodyguard/driver/assassin/whatever-the-hell-he-was down the corridor, your mother’s hand raising to squeeze your shoulder again. He stopped at a door to his right and stepped to the side, his back against the door frame and clasping his fists in front of him, like a guard. He looked at you and nodded toward the room, but then faced forward and gave no indication after that acknowledging your existence.

“It’ll be alright, honey,” your mother whispered into your ear as you slowly stepped into the room, hands balled into fists at your sides. Would your father be awake, be responsive? Would he be covered in casts and bandages to the point of being unrecognizable? Would he be hooked up to machines with an endless array of wires? Would he be okay?

Your father’s bed came into view, but he was blocked by a team of nurses, checking a few machines and muttering to each other in hushed tones. The four women buzzing around his bed like bees around a hive made your stomach churn.

“Oh, the family’s here,” one announced, stepping back and sending you a small smile. The others looked up and quickly finished up whatever they were doing. You still couldn’t see him.

“Is he okay?” you asked, not recognizing the weak voice that came out of your mouth. “What happened? Why—why does he need all of these machines? What—?”

“We’re keeping an eye on him,” answered the nurse, resting two of her hands on your shoulders as if to anchor you down. She smiled but her eyes betrayed nothing, just like your security guard by the door. It was then that you realized everyone here was the same: they’d tell you the bare minimum to keep whatever the hell happened at your dad’s place of work under wraps.

Frustration burned in your veins like hot coals, and your face must’ve shown it, because her hands hastily left your shoulders and the nurses retreated from the room, taking every trace of paperwork with them.

And then you saw him.

He was a pitiful sight, a bundle of bandages and blankets. Half of his face was obscured by gauze which had freshly been changed, his visible eye swollen shut. He had a large chunk of hair missing from the right side of his scalp, more gauze and wrappings covering the area. If you didn’t know better, you’d say he looked… burned.

You sucked in a deep, trembling breath at the sight of him, reaching to hold his hand but finding that it was covered in a bulky cast. Your throat ached, tears rushing down your face despite your effort to keep them walled back.

What happened?

Your mother sat at a chair on the other side of his bed, hands clasped over her mouth as if it would hold back the gasping sobs escaping her. The sound did nothing to strengthen your resolve.

“Daddy…” you whispered, softly touching the unblistered fingertips protruding from his cast. His bandaged face swam in your vision as more tears betrayed you, making the room a blur of bright white light and swimming shapes.

As your mother’s cries echoed throughout the room, mixing with yours in a chorus of heart-wrenching wails, you collapsed to your knees, holding onto your father’s unresponsive fingertips like they’d keep you from drowning in a sea of your own tears.

In that moment, as you felt yourself slip into a void, and saw your rock of a mother look more defeated than you’d ever thought possible, you decided something.

You’d find out what happened to your father.

No matter what it took.

You missed school the next day, refusing to leave your dad’s side. You didn’t eat, you didn’t sleep, you didn’t even go to the bathroom unless you absolutely couldn’t hold it anymore, afraid you’d miss something. The attending for the unit, Dr. Allard, came by a few times to assess your father’s condition, telling you and your mother that they were closely monitoring him at all hours. You even had the lady balls to straight-up ask him what was wrong with your father, and what had happened to cause these broken bones and charred skin, but he just sighed painfully and gave you a look; a look that said, “you know that I can’t tell you that”.

The following day was tough one. You couldn’t afford to miss any more school; after all, you were already playing catch-up. As much as you didn’t want to leave your father’s bedside, it was clear that you had no choice in the matter. You finally stopped arguing with your mom when she assured you that she would call the school if there was any change in your dad’s condition, for better or worse.

You changed into the clothes she had packed for you before she picked you up from school, already knowing that you’d refuse to leave your father’s side for something as trivial as clean clothes. You sighed a little guiltily, thanking her for being so thoughtful. You don’t know how she did it – you were barely functioning and you didn’t have to worry about clothing or transporting or feeding a child on top of it all.

She hugged you tightly and whispered encouraging words in your ear before she released you to the guard. You swung your backpack over your shoulder as you boarded the elevator with Tall, Dark, and Scary.

“You won’t tell me shit either, will you?” you broke the silence as the double doors closed. You could slice the tension in the small space with a butter knife, but in your angry and sleep-deprived state, you really didn’t care. Your father was severely injured and someone was gonna answer for it.

The big guy exhaled sharply through his nose but didn’t look at you or even turn his head in your direction.

“Oh, so it’s gonna be like that, huh?” you challenged, nodding your head bitterly. “I see how it is.”

“Your dad’s safe. That’s all you need to know for now,” he said.

You scoffed. “That’s all I need to know for now? Really?! My dad has had this job for less than a week and he’s laid up in a hospital bed, comatose, covered in burns and—and casts and—what the hell happened to him? Why won’t anyone tell us anything? We deserve to know!”

“Your dad knew what he was signing up for when he took this job,” the man growled, pointing a large finger in your face. You bit your tongue to keep from slapping it away. “It’s not pretty, and you’re in the dark, and you’re pissed. I get it. But there’s a reason you don’t know more right now, and trust me when I say that it’s a damn good one!”

“I seriously doubt when he signed the dotted line that having over half of his body burned within the month was on his mind,” you seethed, venom in every last syllable. “This is complete bullshit!”

Patience and empathy was clearly not one of this man’s strong suits as he pursed his lips and clenched his fists; you even heard a knuckle pop. He didn’t say a word as the elevator doors opened and he strutted down the hall, leaving you fuming behind him.

The car ride was full of silent tension and searing stares. It was at moments like this when you wished you were born with super powers, or were a technical genius, so that you could get the kind of information you wanted. Holding a giant plasma canon in the guy’s face or shooting lasers at him with your eyes would definitely loosen his lips. For now, you’d just have to settle with death glares in the rear view mirror. If he noticed, he didn’t show it. Those stupid sunglasses made it impossible to tell, anyway.

As he pulled up behind the bus lane, you exited the SUV as soon as you possibly could. He yelled something to you but you slammed the door in his face, giving you a faint sense of satisfaction. That’ll show him.

To your shock, Ned and Peter were power-walking toward you. The moment they’d spotted you exiting the noticeable black vehicle in the sea of yellow buses, they weaved through the crowd of high school students. You’d only known the guys for a few days and they were approaching you with such concern in their eyes that you didn’t know what to think.

“Hey, Y/N!” Ned yelled as he came closer, waving as if you couldn’t see them in the crowd. “Y/N!”

You couldn’t help but smile slightly, shaking your head. Ned had a painstakingly clueless air about him sometimes.

“Hey, guys,” you sighed as they stopped in front of you. You tried to grin but the effort made your face hurt so you quickly abandoned the idea.

“Are you okay? What happened?” Peter asked, such genuine concern in his brown eyes and endless kindness in his voice. You felt your shoulders relax.

“Yeah, what happened? You look awful,” Ned said.

You glared and raised your hands questioningly. Peter’s head turned toward Ned slowly, his expression incredulous.

“Gee, thanks, Ned,” you scowled.

The reality of what he’d said seemed to set in on him, and Ned’s mouth formed an 'O’.

“I—I didn’t mean that you don’t look good,” Ned said quickly. “I mean, you’re like the hottest girl in school right now anyway, right, Peter?”

Your stare morphed from a glare to confusion, and you looked to Peter. He suddenly seemed intensely uncomfortable. Ned looked at Peter for support, raising his eyebrows, begging for his friend to help him out of the hole he’d dug.

“Uh, I mean, you—you always look g-good… great,” Peter gulped, glaring at Ned and meeting your eyes anxiously.

“Always,” Ned added enthusiastically, nodding at you over Peter’s shoulder.

You huffed out a weak laugh. Ned looked relieved and Peter looked like he wanted to melt into a puddle. “Nice save, guys.”

The bell rang and you turned toward the front doors, following the large crowd of your classmates. You assumed that Ned and Peter were right behind you, but when you turned to talk to them, you discovered that they were a few feet back, Peter whispering furiously at Ned. You grinned to yourself, thinking of Peter’s flustered compliments. A single butterfly flapped its wings inside your stomach, and you savored the feeling—something other than fury and hopelessness was a refreshing and welcome change.

The wolf whistles that followed you down the hallway that morning went in one ear and out the other. Your mind was floating through the hospital and into the room with your father. Your hands shook as you opened your locker, unable to twist the correct combination until your third try. Before the lock finally gave, you were about to start crying.

“Hey, do you need any help with your books?” came a soft voice beside you, and the frustrated tears threatening to spill retreated at the sound.

“No, it’s okay, Peter,” you said, stuffing two binders into your backpack and putting three books into your locker. “I’m just a little… distracted, is all.”

“I get it,” he said, swinging his backpack over one shoulder. “If—if you want to talk about it, I’ve been told I’m a good listener. Me and Ned. We’re good listeners.”

You smiled but it didn’t reach your eyes, an all-too-familiar ache returning to the middle of your throat.

“Um, maybe at lunch. It’s kind of a long story.”

“Sure,” Peter nodded, eager to accommodate. You turned to walk toward homeroom and Peter stayed by your side, talking about the next machine that he and Ned were building for their class later in the day. It was obvious that he was doing his best to make conversation and keep your mind off of whatever was bothering you, and you were thankful. As far as you could tell, Peter was a total saint.

He stopped at the classroom door, suddenly self-conscious. He reached to scratch at the back of his neck, and the movement caught your eye.

“Sorry, you probably don’t even care about robotics,” he apologized, almost embarrassed.

“No it’s okay—”

“Most people don’t.”

“Oh, Peter, anything you say is a thousand times better than what’s going on in my head right now,” you smiled, touched. It did reach your eyes this time, and your throat ached for a different reason. You lightly brushed his arm before hooking your thumbs back under you backpack straps.

Peter Parker could read the phone book to you and you’d listen with rapt attention.

He glanced at his forearm where you’d touched him, and then up to your eyes. They were so chocolate. There was a mix of relief and something else swimming in them, and whatever the something else was, it added a butterfly or two to the dancing colony in your stomach.

Peter seemed to catch himself. He pointed behind him. “I—I need to go. I’ve already been late to English twice this week.”

You grinned. Now that you thought about it, Peter was almost late wherever he went.

“See you at lunch, Parker.” The corner of your lips pulled up.

“Yeah,” he nodded, backing away but still facing you, “yeah. Okay, bye.”

Your hands didn’t leave your backpack straps but you stretched out your fingers and wiggled them as a farewell. He smiled—then proceeded to back into someone and almost make them drop their books.

You snorted to yourself as he exclaimed “Sorry!” at the unsuspecting guy and sprinted away down the hall.

Ned made small talk with you in homeroom, and you could tell that he was doing his best to distract you just like Peter was. There must’ve been something about your face that revealed the turmoil tossing and turning beneath.

Lunch was a blessing. By the time the bell rang and freed you, the frustration and need to vent were so strong that you were about to burst. Ned and Peter were smart guys and longtime New-Yorkers with plenty of experience in the alien invasion department. Surely they’d have some idea of what was going on.

You were the last to sit down at what had become your friend group’s designated table. Ned and Peter were in a deep discussion that cut off the second you were within earshot. You tried not to be bothered by the fact that they always seemed to be changing subjects around you—after all, they’d been best friends for years and they barely knew you. But it bugged you nonetheless.

“So, you promised us a juicy story at lunch today,” Ned reminded you, tone light and teasing. You’d much rather his nonchalant approach than anyone treating you like a cracking china doll.

You sighed and picked up your plastic fork, prodding what was supposed to be spaghetti on your plate. With your stay in the hospital, packing lunch hadn’t been an option.

“Where do I even start?” you exhaled, dropping the fork and pushing the plate away. You’d suddenly lost your appetite, not that you had much of one in the first place. “With the bulletproof SUV? Or what about the bodyguard that constantly has a stick shoved up his ass?”

“What?” Peter asked, clearly confused.

You rubbed your eyes and colorful stars appeared in the corners of your vision. “It’s my dad. There was some kind of accident at his office and he’s in the hospital.”

“Oh, that sucks,” Ned breathed. “I’m so sorry.”

“What happened?” Peter asked, his brows pulled together.

“I don’t even know,” you chuckled hopelessly. “They won’t tell us anything. All the doctor will say is, 'we’re keeping an eye on him’. Every time I ask someone a question I get looked at like I’m about to have a nervous breakdown or get shot, one of the two.”

“Y/N… what exactly does your dad do?” Peter inquired, leaning forward slightly.

“It’s a government job,” you explained. “I think the official term for his division is Alien Affairs or something. I don’t even know what he does. I don’t think I’m supposed to.”

Something in Peter’s body language changed. Ned’s eyes snapped to him before landing back on you.

“The bodyguard makes sense then…” Ned muttered, almost to himself.

“And get this,” you continued, the weight of holding all of your frustrations inside beginning to lift, “the place is like a prison. No one goes in or out without armed supervision, even family. And the floors above and below where government employees are kept are empty, for 'security reasons’, they said. What the hell does that even mean?”

“Why would they be guarding a hospital if there was just an 'accident’?” Ned wondered.

“Because it probably wasn’t an accident,” Peter replied, looking at one spot on the table. You could practically hear the whir of wheels turning inside of his brain.

“What—what do you mean it wasn’t an accident?” you blanched, trying to catch his eye, but his were still glued to the table.

He finally met your prodding gaze and suddenly seemed a little nervous, like he had a time limit to get all of the words out. “I mean, y-you know, Mr. Stark deals with the government all the time. He says they lie more than they tell the truth. Everything is, uh, always covered up until they’re sure they aren’t liable for anything.”

You shrugged and rolled your eyes at the accuracy. “Sounds about right.”

“Did they at least mention when he’d be released?” Ned asked.

You shook your head and looked at your lap, fighting back the stinging at the corner of your eyes. “No. But it won’t be anytime soon. You should’ve seen him… he looks burned.”

“Do you think there was a fire or something?” Ned asked.

“Or maybe it’s chemical burns. I don’t know,” you sighed. “It’s the not knowing that’s the worst.”

Peter had gone quiet, and you found yourself biting the inside of your cheek. Was he awkward around talk of grief? Maybe he was uncomfortable. But no, something told you, he’s thinking. Thinking hard.

“What is it, Peter?” you asked, your voice a mixture of hope and caution. What if he said something that you didn’t want to hear?

He suddenly bolted out of his seat, his chair tumbling to the floor with a loud clatter. He was grabbing his things and stuffing them into his backpack. His mind was obviously somewhere that wasn’t the cafeteria.

He was leaving. Again.

“Dude, where are you going?” Ned questioned, but whether it was for his benefit or yours, you didn’t know.

Peter was backing away, making to run, looking right at you. “It’s Mr. Stark, I forgot about—about that thing. Cover for me in Chemistry, Y/N?”

“Uh—”

But he was gone in a flash of chocolate hair and a bouncing backpack.

body_abstract:
“The Man Behind the Mask”

Pt 4

Peter Parker x reader

Warnings: Hospital, description of injured family member

Summary: You’ve recently moved to Queens, New York after your father finds a new job with the U.S. government handling alien affairs in the city. You’ve grown up in a small town, and it’s your junior year of high school; culture shock takes a whole new meaning when you’re saved by the famed new web-slinging Avenger - and when you meet a new group of friends at Midtown High that seem to always be hiding something. But things quickly get personal.

Masterlist / Pt 1 – Pt 2 – Pt 3

It was a blur of sounds and lights and faces. The black car your mother had taken to the school was a company car – a government car. With a driver. It all seemed so cold and official. Your mom was crying beside you in the backseat but unsuccessfully trying to hide it, for your sake. She tried to explain through her sobs what happened at your father’s workplace, but it seemed that she didn’t really know many details at all. Everything government-related was secretive, especially when it concerned alien affairs, and especially when the word ‘accident’ was thrown around. You were sure that they were keeping you and your mother in the dark about what happened – you’d bet money that they always knew more than they were saying.

The man in the suit and sunglasses behind the wheel never said a word and his facial expression never changed throughout the drive to the hospital. He seemed entirely uninviting. You noticed a bulge at his side underneath his suit jacket, and it didn’t take more than a moment to realize that it was a gun. Of course it was. What was he, security detail? To keep you and your mother safe or to maybe keep you two from probing more than you should be into the incident? Either way, you found his presence completely unnecessary and a bit unnerving.

Pulling up to the hospital, you threw open the SUV door before the vehicle was completely stopped and ran toward the doors despite your mother’s protests. The lobby was cold and sterile, bringing chill bumps to your arms. Your sense of foreboding only heightened.

“Baby, don’t go running off like that,” you heard your mother beg from behind you, resting her shaking hands on your shoulders. “I know that you want to see your dad, and—and that this is scary, but we’ve gotta stick together.”

[[MORE]]

You didn’t respond, watching as the large man that drove the SUV motion for you two to follow him down a nearby hallway. You followed his lead in a blur. The hospital wing was deserted, all the doors down the blindingly white hallway ajar, allowing you to peer into the rooms. Every bed was perfectly made, a fresh vase of flowers by every window. It was almost eerie.

“For security reasons,” came a deep voice through the haze. You looked into the dark sunglasses that looked back at you before they turned away. “No one underneath or above the floor our people are on. We don’t want anyone here that shouldn’t be, and it’s a hell of a lot easier to spot someone who doesn’t belong when no one should be in this hallway in the first place.”

“Surely – I mean, but patients were here, right?” you stuttered. “Where did they go?”

“Somewhere else,” he replied shortly, making it clear that the conversation was over. You glanced back at your mother, who shrugged and gave you a look that clearly said “stop asking questions”.

The three of you approached an elevator at the end of the off-putting corridor. There wasn’t an up or down button, but a keypad and a finger print scanner. Your brows furrowed. Why in the hell was this place like a disguised prison instead of a hospital? Who—or what—was your father being protected from? A shiver ran down your spine.

The large man obscured your view with his shoulder blades, leaning down to punch in a combination and scan his fingerprint. It was clear that you weren’t supposed to know how to get into this elevator without supervision. But this was your dad—he didn’t need protecting from you, from his family.

A loud alarm sounded throughout the hallway as the elevator arrived. You were sure that everyone in the hospital could hear it, and maybe that was the point—no surprise visitors. The blaring ceased as the doors opened and the three of you stepped inside. It was stainless steel and spotless, sterile, like everything else around you. You weren’t sure if this was comforting you, or the opposite. It was clean, but there was no warmth.

The elevator did not have any indicator or screen that told you what floor you were arriving to. You gulped as the doors finally parted for you, a hallway even more blindingly white meeting your vision, but this time it was full of people bustling around, all seemingly in a hurry. Nurses were in protective suits, masks covering their faces, as they entered a room at the very end of the hallway with a large caution indicator flashing above it. You couldn’t believe what you were seeing. It was like a scene from a science fiction movie.

“Your father isn’t in there,” a deep voice said, pulling you from your thoughts. Was that meant to be comforting? You looked up at his stony face, his lense-covered eyes betraying nothing. He simply motioned to his right, down a separate hallway. You followed the bodyguard/driver/assassin/whatever-the-hell-he-was down the corridor, your mother’s hand raising to squeeze your shoulder again. He stopped at a door to his right and stepped to the side, his back against the door frame and clasping his fists in front of him, like a guard. He looked at you and nodded toward the room, but then faced forward and gave no indication after that acknowledging your existence.

“It’ll be alright, honey,” your mother whispered into your ear as you slowly stepped into the room, hands balled into fists at your sides. Would your father be awake, be responsive? Would he be covered in casts and bandages to the point of being unrecognizable? Would he be hooked up to machines with an endless array of wires? Would he be okay?

Your father’s bed came into view, but he was blocked by a team of nurses, checking a few machines and muttering to each other in hushed tones. The four women buzzing around his bed like bees around a hive made your stomach churn.

“Oh, the family’s here,” one announced, stepping back and sending you a small smile. The others looked up and quickly finished up whatever they were doing. You still couldn’t see him.

“Is he okay?” you asked, not recognizing the weak voice that came out of your mouth. “What happened? Why—why does he need all of these machines? What—?”

“We’re keeping an eye on him,” answered the nurse, resting two of her hands on your shoulders as if to anchor you down. She smiled but her eyes betrayed nothing, just like your security guard by the door. It was then that you realized everyone here was the same: they’d tell you the bare minimum to keep whatever the hell happened at your dad’s place of work under wraps.

Frustration burned in your veins like hot coals, and your face must’ve shown it, because her hands hastily left your shoulders and the nurses retreated from the room, taking every trace of paperwork with them.

And then you saw him.

He was a pitiful sight, a bundle of bandages and blankets. Half of his face was obscured by gauze which had freshly been changed, his visible eye swollen shut. He had a large chunk of hair missing from the right side of his scalp, more gauze and wrappings covering the area. If you didn’t know better, you’d say he looked… burned.

You sucked in a deep, trembling breath at the sight of him, reaching to hold his hand but finding that it was covered in a bulky cast. Your throat ached, tears rushing down your face despite your effort to keep them walled back.

What happened?

Your mother sat at a chair on the other side of his bed, hands clasped over her mouth as if it would hold back the gasping sobs escaping her. The sound did nothing to strengthen your resolve.

“Daddy…” you whispered, softly touching the unblistered fingertips protruding from his cast. His bandaged face swam in your vision as more tears betrayed you, making the room a blur of bright white light and swimming shapes.

As your mother’s cries echoed throughout the room, mixing with yours in a chorus of heart-wrenching wails, you collapsed to your knees, holding onto your father’s unresponsive fingertips like they’d keep you from drowning in a sea of your own tears.

In that moment, as you felt yourself slip into a void, and saw your rock of a mother look more defeated than you’d ever thought possible, you decided something.

You’d find out what happened to your father.

No matter what it took.

You missed school the next day, refusing to leave your dad’s side. You didn’t eat, you didn’t sleep, you didn’t even go to the bathroom unless you absolutely couldn’t hold it anymore, afraid you’d miss something. The attending for the unit, Dr. Allard, came by a few times to assess your father’s condition, telling you and your mother that they were closely monitoring him at all hours. You even had the lady balls to straight-up ask him what was wrong with your father, and what had happened to cause these broken bones and charred skin, but he just sighed painfully and gave you a look; a look that said, “you know that I can’t tell you that”.

The following day was tough one. You couldn’t afford to miss any more school; after all, you were already playing catch-up. As much as you didn’t want to leave your father’s bedside, it was clear that you had no choice in the matter. You finally stopped arguing with your mom when she assured you that she would call the school if there was any change in your dad’s condition, for better or worse.

You changed into the clothes she had packed for you before she picked you up from school, already knowing that you’d refuse to leave your father’s side for something as trivial as clean clothes. You sighed a little guiltily, thanking her for being so thoughtful. You don’t know how she did it – you were barely functioning and you didn’t have to worry about clothing or transporting or feeding a child on top of it all.

She hugged you tightly and whispered encouraging words in your ear before she released you to the guard. You swung your backpack over your shoulder as you boarded the elevator with Tall, Dark, and Scary.

“You won’t tell me shit either, will you?” you broke the silence as the double doors closed. You could slice the tension in the small space with a butter knife, but in your angry and sleep-deprived state, you really didn’t care. Your father was severely injured and someone was gonna answer for it.

The big guy exhaled sharply through his nose but didn’t look at you or even turn his head in your direction.

“Oh, so it’s gonna be like that, huh?” you challenged, nodding your head bitterly. “I see how it is.”

“Your dad’s safe. That’s all you need to know for now,” he said.

You scoffed. “That’s all I need to know for now? Really?! My dad has had this job for less than a week and he’s laid up in a hospital bed, comatose, covered in burns and—and casts and—what the hell happened to him? Why won’t anyone tell us anything? We deserve to know!”

“Your dad knew what he was signing up for when he took this job,” the man growled, pointing a large finger in your face. You bit your tongue to keep from slapping it away. “It’s not pretty, and you’re in the dark, and you’re pissed. I get it. “I seriously doubt when he signed the dotted line that having over half of his body burned within the month was on his mind,” you seethed, venom in every last syllable. “This is complete bullshit!”

You shook your head and looked at your lap, fighting back the stinging at the corner of your eyes. “No. But it won’t be anytime soon. You should’ve seen him… he looks burned.”

“Do you think there was a fire or something?” Ned asked.

“Or maybe it’s chemical burns. I don’t know,” you sighed. “It’s the not knowing that’s the worst.”

Peter had gone quiet, and you found yourself biting the inside of your cheek. Was he awkward around talk of grief? Maybe he was uncomfortable. But no, something told you, he’s thinking. Thinking hard.

“What is it, Peter?” you asked, your voice a mixture of hope and caution. What if he said something that you didn’t want to hear?

He was leaving. Again.

“Dude, where are you going?” Ned questioned, but whether it was for his benefit or yours, you didn’t know.

Peter was backing away, making to run, looking right at you. “It’s Mr. Stark, I forgot about—about that thing. Cover for me in Chemistry, Y/N?”

“The Man Behind the Mask”

Pt 4

Peter Parker x reader

Warnings: Hospital, description of injured family member

Summary: You’ve recently moved to Queens, New York after your father finds a new job with the U.S. government handling alien affairs in the city. You’ve grown up in a small town, and it’s your junior year of high school; culture shock takes a whole new meaning when you’re saved by the famed new web-slinging Avenger - and when you meet a new group of friends at Midtown High that seem to always be hiding something. But things quickly get personal.

Masterlist / Pt 1 – Pt 2 – Pt 3

It was a blur of sounds and lights and faces. The black car your mother had taken to the school was a company car – a government car. With a driver. It all seemed so cold and official. Your mom was crying beside you in the backseat but unsuccessfully trying to hide it, for your sake. She tried to explain through her sobs what happened at your father’s workplace, but it seemed that she didn’t really know many details at all. Everything government-related was secretive, especially when it concerned alien affairs, and especially when the word ‘accident’ was thrown around. You were sure that they were keeping you and your mother in the dark about what happened – you’d bet money that they always knew more than they were saying.

The man in the suit and sunglasses behind the wheel never said a word and his facial expression never changed throughout the drive to the hospital. He seemed entirely uninviting. You noticed a bulge at his side underneath his suit jacket, and it didn’t take more than a moment to realize that it was a gun. Of course it was. What was he, security detail? To keep you and your mother safe or to maybe keep you two from probing more than you should be into the incident? Either way, you found his presence completely unnecessary and a bit unnerving.

Pulling up to the hospital, you threw open the SUV door before the vehicle was completely stopped and ran toward the doors despite your mother’s protests. The lobby was cold and sterile, bringing chill bumps to your arms. Your sense of foreboding only heightened.

“Baby, don’t go running off like that,” you heard your mother beg from behind you, resting her shaking hands on your shoulders. “I know that you want to see your dad, and—and that this is scary, but we’ve gotta stick together.”

[[MORE]]

You didn’t respond, watching as the large man that drove the SUV motion for you two to follow him down a nearby hallway. You followed his lead in a blur. The hospital wing was deserted, all the doors down the blindingly white hallway ajar, allowing you to peer into the rooms. Every bed was perfectly made, a fresh vase of flowers by every window. It was almost eerie.

“For security reasons,” came a deep voice through the haze. You looked into the dark sunglasses that looked back at you before they turned away. “No one underneath or above the floor our people are on. We don’t want anyone here that shouldn’t be, and it’s a hell of a lot easier to spot someone who doesn’t belong when no one should be in this hallway in the first place.”

“Surely – I mean, but patients were here, right?” you stuttered. “Where did they go?”

“Somewhere else,” he replied shortly, making it clear that the conversation was over. You glanced back at your mother, who shrugged and gave you a look that clearly said “stop asking questions”.

The three of you approached an elevator at the end of the off-putting corridor. There wasn’t an up or down button, but a keypad and a finger print scanner. Your brows furrowed. Why in the hell was this place like a disguised prison instead of a hospital? Who—or what—was your father being protected from? A shiver ran down your spine.

The large man obscured your view with his shoulder blades, leaning down to punch in a combination and scan his fingerprint. It was clear that you weren’t supposed to know how to get into this elevator without supervision. But this was your dad—he didn’t need protecting from you, from his family.

A loud alarm sounded throughout the hallway as the elevator arrived. You were sure that everyone in the hospital could hear it, and maybe that was the point—no surprise visitors. The blaring ceased as the doors opened and the three of you stepped inside. It was stainless steel and spotless, sterile, like everything else around you. You weren’t sure if this was comforting you, or the opposite. It was clean, but there was no warmth.

The elevator did not have any indicator or screen that told you what floor you were arriving to. You gulped as the doors finally parted for you, a hallway even more blindingly white meeting your vision, but this time it was full of people bustling around, all seemingly in a hurry. Nurses were in protective suits, masks covering their faces, as they entered a room at the very end of the hallway with a large caution indicator flashing above it. You couldn’t believe what you were seeing. It was like a scene from a science fiction movie.

“Your father isn’t in there,” a deep voice said, pulling you from your thoughts. Was that meant to be comforting? You looked up at his stony face, his lense-covered eyes betraying nothing. He simply motioned to his right, down a separate hallway. You followed the bodyguard/driver/assassin/whatever-the-hell-he-was down the corridor, your mother’s hand raising to squeeze your shoulder again. He stopped at a door to his right and stepped to the side, his back against the door frame and clasping his fists in front of him, like a guard. He looked at you and nodded toward the room, but then faced forward and gave no indication after that acknowledging your existence.

“It’ll be alright, honey,” your mother whispered into your ear as you slowly stepped into the room, hands balled into fists at your sides. Would your father be awake, be responsive? Would he be covered in casts and bandages to the point of being unrecognizable? Would he be hooked up to machines with an endless array of wires? Would he be okay?

Your father’s bed came into view, but he was blocked by a team of nurses, checking a few machines and muttering to each other in hushed tones. The four women buzzing around his bed like bees around a hive made your stomach churn.

“Oh, the family’s here,” one announced, stepping back and sending you a small smile. The others looked up and quickly finished up whatever they were doing. You still couldn’t see him.

“Is he okay?” you asked, not recognizing the weak voice that came out of your mouth. “What happened? Why—why does he need all of these machines? What—?”

“We’re keeping an eye on him,” answered the nurse, resting two of her hands on your shoulders as if to anchor you down. She smiled but her eyes betrayed nothing, just like your security guard by the door. It was then that you realized everyone here was the same: they’d tell you the bare minimum to keep whatever the hell happened at your dad’s place of work under wraps.

Frustration burned in your veins like hot coals, and your face must’ve shown it, because her hands hastily left your shoulders and the nurses retreated from the room, taking every trace of paperwork with them.

And then you saw him.

He was a pitiful sight, a bundle of bandages and blankets. Half of his face was obscured by gauze which had freshly been changed, his visible eye swollen shut. He had a large chunk of hair missing from the right side of his scalp, more gauze and wrappings covering the area. If you didn’t know better, you’d say he looked… burned.

You sucked in a deep, trembling breath at the sight of him, reaching to hold his hand but finding that it was covered in a bulky cast. Your throat ached, tears rushing down your face despite your effort to keep them walled back.

What happened?

Your mother sat at a chair on the other side of his bed, hands clasped over her mouth as if it would hold back the gasping sobs escaping her. The sound did nothing to strengthen your resolve.

“Daddy…” you whispered, softly touching the unblistered fingertips protruding from his cast. His bandaged face swam in your vision as more tears betrayed you, making the room a blur of bright white light and swimming shapes.

As your mother’s cries echoed throughout the room, mixing with yours in a chorus of heart-wrenching wails, you collapsed to your knees, holding onto your father’s unresponsive fingertips like they’d keep you from drowning in a sea of your own tears.

In that moment, as you felt yourself slip into a void, and saw your rock of a mother look more defeated than you’d ever thought possible, you decided something.

You’d find out what happened to your father.

No matter what it took.

You missed school the next day, refusing to leave your dad’s side. You didn’t eat, you didn’t sleep, you didn’t even go to the bathroom unless you absolutely couldn’t hold it anymore, afraid you’d miss something. The attending for the unit, Dr. Allard, came by a few times to assess your father’s condition, telling you and your mother that they were closely monitoring him at all hours. You even had the lady balls to straight-up ask him what was wrong with your father, and what had happened to cause these broken bones and charred skin, but he just sighed painfully and gave you a look; a look that said, “you know that I can’t tell you that”.

The following day was tough one. You couldn’t afford to miss any more school; after all, you were already playing catch-up. As much as you didn’t want to leave your father’s bedside, it was clear that you had no choice in the matter. You finally stopped arguing with your mom when she assured you that she would call the school if there was any change in your dad’s condition, for better or worse.

You changed into the clothes she had packed for you before she picked you up from school, already knowing that you’d refuse to leave your father’s side for something as trivial as clean clothes. You sighed a little guiltily, thanking her for being so thoughtful. You don’t know how she did it – you were barely functioning and you didn’t have to worry about clothing or transporting or feeding a child on top of it all.

She hugged you tightly and whispered encouraging words in your ear before she released you to the guard. You swung your backpack over your shoulder as you boarded the elevator with Tall, Dark, and Scary.

“You won’t tell me shit either, will you?” you broke the silence as the double doors closed. You could slice the tension in the small space with a butter knife, but in your angry and sleep-deprived state, you really didn’t care. Your father was severely injured and someone was gonna answer for it.

The big guy exhaled sharply through his nose but didn’t look at you or even turn his head in your direction.

“Oh, so it’s gonna be like that, huh?” you challenged, nodding your head bitterly. “I see how it is.”

“Your dad’s safe. That’s all you need to know for now,” he said.

You scoffed. “That’s all I need to know for now? Really?! My dad has had this job for less than a week and he’s laid up in a hospital bed, comatose, covered in burns and—and casts and—what the hell happened to him? Why won’t anyone tell us anything? We deserve to know!”

“Your dad knew what he was signing up for when he took this job,” the man growled, pointing a large finger in your face. You bit your tongue to keep from slapping it away. “It’s not pretty, and you’re in the dark, and you’re pissed. I get it. But there’s a reason you don’t know more right now, and trust me when I say that it’s a damn good one!”

“I seriously doubt when he signed the dotted line that having over half of his body burned within the month was on his mind,” you seethed, venom in every last syllable. “This is complete bullshit!”

Patience and empathy was clearly not one of this man’s strong suits as he pursed his lips and clenched his fists; you even heard a knuckle pop. He didn’t say a word as the elevator doors opened and he strutted down the hall, leaving you fuming behind him.

The car ride was full of silent tension and searing stares. It was at moments like this when you wished you were born with super powers, or were a technical genius, so that you could get the kind of information you wanted. Holding a giant plasma canon in the guy’s face or shooting lasers at him with your eyes would definitely loosen his lips. For now, you’d just have to settle with death glares in the rear view mirror. If he noticed, he didn’t show it. Those stupid sunglasses made it impossible to tell, anyway.

As he pulled up behind the bus lane, you exited the SUV as soon as you possibly could. He yelled something to you but you slammed the door in his face, giving you a faint sense of satisfaction. That’ll show him.

To your shock, Ned and Peter were power-walking toward you. The moment they’d spotted you exiting the noticeable black vehicle in the sea of yellow buses, they weaved through the crowd of high school students. You’d only known the guys for a few days and they were approaching you with such concern in their eyes that you didn’t know what to think.

“Hey, Y/N!” Ned yelled as he came closer, waving as if you couldn’t see them in the crowd. “Y/N!”

You couldn’t help but smile slightly, shaking your head. Ned had a painstakingly clueless air about him sometimes.

“Hey, guys,” you sighed as they stopped in front of you. You tried to grin but the effort made your face hurt so you quickly abandoned the idea.

“Are you okay? What happened?” Peter asked, such genuine concern in his brown eyes and endless kindness in his voice. You felt your shoulders relax.

“Yeah, what happened? You look awful,” Ned said.

You glared and raised your hands questioningly. Peter’s head turned toward Ned slowly, his expression incredulous.

“Gee, thanks, Ned,” you scowled.

The reality of what he’d said seemed to set in on him, and Ned’s mouth formed an 'O’.

“I—I didn’t mean that you don’t look good,” Ned said quickly. “I mean, you’re like the hottest girl in school right now anyway, right, Peter?”

Your stare morphed from a glare to confusion, and you looked to Peter. He suddenly seemed intensely uncomfortable. Ned looked at Peter for support, raising his eyebrows, begging for his friend to help him out of the hole he’d dug.

“Uh, I mean, you—you always look g-good… great,” Peter gulped, glaring at Ned and meeting your eyes anxiously.

“Always,” Ned added enthusiastically, nodding at you over Peter’s shoulder.

You huffed out a weak laugh. Ned looked relieved and Peter looked like he wanted to melt into a puddle. “Nice save, guys.”

The bell rang and you turned toward the front doors, following the large crowd of your classmates. You assumed that Ned and Peter were right behind you, but when you turned to talk to them, you discovered that they were a few feet back, Peter whispering furiously at Ned. You grinned to yourself, thinking of Peter’s flustered compliments. A single butterfly flapped its wings inside your stomach, and you savored the feeling—something other than fury and hopelessness was a refreshing and welcome change.

The wolf whistles that followed you down the hallway that morning went in one ear and out the other. Your mind was floating through the hospital and into the room with your father. Your hands shook as you opened your locker, unable to twist the correct combination until your third try. Before the lock finally gave, you were about to start crying.

“Hey, do you need any help with your books?” came a soft voice beside you, and the frustrated tears threatening to spill retreated at the sound.

“No, it’s okay, Peter,” you said, stuffing two binders into your backpack and putting three books into your locker. “I’m just a little… distracted, is all.”

“I get it,” he said, swinging his backpack over one shoulder. “If—if you want to talk about it, I’ve been told I’m a good listener. Me and Ned. We’re good listeners.”

You smiled but it didn’t reach your eyes, an all-too-familiar ache returning to the middle of your throat.

“Um, maybe at lunch. It’s kind of a long story.”

“Sure,” Peter nodded, eager to accommodate. You turned to walk toward homeroom and Peter stayed by your side, talking about the next machine that he and Ned were building for their class later in the day. It was obvious that he was doing his best to make conversation and keep your mind off of whatever was bothering you, and you were thankful. As far as you could tell, Peter was a total saint.

He stopped at the classroom door, suddenly self-conscious. He reached to scratch at the back of his neck, and the movement caught your eye.

“Sorry, you probably don’t even care about robotics,” he apologized, almost embarrassed.

“No it’s okay—”

“Most people don’t.”

“Oh, Peter, anything you say is a thousand times better than what’s going on in my head right now,” you smiled, touched. It did reach your eyes this time, and your throat ached for a different reason. You lightly brushed his arm before hooking your thumbs back under you backpack straps.

Peter Parker could read the phone book to you and you’d listen with rapt attention.

He glanced at his forearm where you’d touched him, and then up to your eyes. They were so chocolate. There was a mix of relief and something else swimming in them, and whatever the something else was, it added a butterfly or two to the dancing colony in your stomach.

Peter seemed to catch himself. He pointed behind him. “I—I need to go. I’ve already been late to English twice this week.”

You grinned. Now that you thought about it, Peter was almost late wherever he went.

“See you at lunch, Parker.” The corner of your lips pulled up.

“Yeah,” he nodded, backing away but still facing you, “yeah. Okay, bye.”

Your hands didn’t leave your backpack straps but you stretched out your fingers and wiggled them as a farewell. He smiled—then proceeded to back into someone and almost make them drop their books.

You snorted to yourself as he exclaimed “Sorry!” at the unsuspecting guy and sprinted away down the hall.

Ned made small talk with you in homeroom, and you could tell that he was doing his best to distract you just like Peter was. There must’ve been something about your face that revealed the turmoil tossing and turning beneath.

Lunch was a blessing. By the time the bell rang and freed you, the frustration and need to vent were so strong that you were about to burst. Ned and Peter were smart guys and longtime New-Yorkers with plenty of experience in the alien invasion department. Surely they’d have some idea of what was going on.

You were the last to sit down at what had become your friend group’s designated table. Ned and Peter were in a deep discussion that cut off the second you were within earshot. You tried not to be bothered by the fact that they always seemed to be changing subjects around you—after all, they’d been best friends for years and they barely knew you. But it bugged you nonetheless.

“So, you promised us a juicy story at lunch today,” Ned reminded you, tone light and teasing. You’d much rather his nonchalant approach than anyone treating you like a cracking china doll.

You sighed and picked up your plastic fork, prodding what was supposed to be spaghetti on your plate. With your stay in the hospital, packing lunch hadn’t been an option.

“Where do I even start?” you exhaled, dropping the fork and pushing the plate away. You’d suddenly lost your appetite, not that you had much of one in the first place. “With the bulletproof SUV? Or what about the bodyguard that constantly has a stick shoved up his ass?”

“What?” Peter asked, clearly confused.

You rubbed your eyes and colorful stars appeared in the corners of your vision. “It’s my dad. There was some kind of accident at his office and he’s in the hospital.”

“Oh, that sucks,” Ned breathed. “I’m so sorry.”

“What happened?” Peter asked, his brows pulled together.

“I don’t even know,” you chuckled hopelessly. “They won’t tell us anything. All the doctor will say is, 'we’re keeping an eye on him’. Every time I ask someone a question I get looked at like I’m about to have a nervous breakdown or get shot, one of the two.”

“Y/N… what exactly does your dad do?” Peter inquired, leaning forward slightly.

“It’s a government job,” you explained. “I think the official term for his division is Alien Affairs or something. I don’t even know what he does. I don’t think I’m supposed to.”

Something in Peter’s body language changed. Ned’s eyes snapped to him before landing back on you.

“The bodyguard makes sense then…” Ned muttered, almost to himself.

“And get this,” you continued, the weight of holding all of your frustrations inside beginning to lift, “the place is like a prison. No one goes in or out without armed supervision, even family. And the floors above and below where government employees are kept are empty, for 'security reasons’, they said. What the hell does that even mean?”

“Why would they be guarding a hospital if there was just an 'accident’?” Ned wondered.

“Because it probably wasn’t an accident,” Peter replied, looking at one spot on the table. You could practically hear the whir of wheels turning inside of his brain.

“What—what do you mean it wasn’t an accident?” you blanched, trying to catch his eye, but his were still glued to the table.

He finally met your prodding gaze and suddenly seemed a little nervous, like he had a time limit to get all of the words out. “I mean, y-you know, Mr. Stark deals with the government all the time. He says they lie more than they tell the truth. Everything is, uh, always covered up until they’re sure they aren’t liable for anything.”

You shrugged and rolled your eyes at the accuracy. “Sounds about right.”

“Did they at least mention when he’d be released?” Ned asked.

You shook your head and looked at your lap, fighting back the stinging at the corner of your eyes. “No. But it won’t be anytime soon. You should’ve seen him… he looks burned.”

“Do you think there was a fire or something?” Ned asked.

“Or maybe it’s chemical burns. I don’t know,” you sighed. “It’s the not knowing that’s the worst.”

Peter had gone quiet, and you found yourself biting the inside of your cheek. Was he awkward around talk of grief? Maybe he was uncomfortable. But no, something told you, he’s thinking. Thinking hard.

“What is it, Peter?” you asked, your voice a mixture of hope and caution. What if he said something that you didn’t want to hear?

He suddenly bolted out of his seat, his chair tumbling to the floor with a loud clatter. He was grabbing his things and stuffing them into his backpack. His mind was obviously somewhere that wasn’t the cafeteria.

He was leaving. Again.

“Dude, where are you going?” Ned questioned, but whether it was for his benefit or yours, you didn’t know.

Peter was backing away, making to run, looking right at you. “It’s Mr. Stark, I forgot about—about that thing. Cover for me in Chemistry, Y/N?”

“Uh—”

But he was gone in a flash of chocolate hair and a bouncing backpack.

Pt 5

“Daddy…” you whispered, softly touching the unblistered fingertips protruding from his cast. His bandaged face swam in your vision as more tears betrayed you, making the room a blur of bright white light and swimming shapes.

As your mother’s cries echoed throughout the room, mixing with yours in a chorus of heart-wrenching wails, you collapsed to your knees, holding onto your father’s unresponsive fingertips like they’d keep you from drowning in a sea of your own tears.

In that moment, as you felt yourself slip into a void, and saw your rock of a mother look more defeated than you’d ever thought possible, you decided something.

You’d find out what happened to your father.

No matter what it took.

You missed school the next day, refusing to leave your dad’s side. You didn’t eat, you didn’t sleep, you didn’t even go to the bathroom unless you absolutely couldn’t hold it anymore, afraid you’d miss something. The attending for the unit, Dr. Allard, came by a few times to assess your father’s condition, telling you and your mother that they were closely monitoring him at all hours. You even had the lady balls to straight-up ask him what was wrong with your father, and what had happened to cause these broken bones and charred skin, but he just sighed painfully and gave you a look; a look that said, “you know that I can’t tell you that”.

The following day was tough one. You couldn’t afford to miss any more school; after all, you were already playing catch-up. As much as you didn’t want to leave your father’s bedside, it was clear that you had no choice in the matter. You finally stopped arguing with your mom when she assured you that she would call the school if there was any change in your dad’s condition, for better or worse.

You changed into the clothes she had packed for you before she picked you up from school, already knowing that you’d refuse to leave your father’s side for something as trivial as clean clothes. You sighed a little guiltily, thanking her for being so thoughtful. You don’t know how she did it – you were barely functioning and you didn’t have to worry about clothing or transporting or feeding a child on top of it all.

She hugged you tightly and whispered encouraging words in your ear before she released you to the guard. You swung your backpack over your shoulder as you boarded the elevator with Tall, Dark, and Scary.

“You won’t tell me shit either, will you?” you broke the silence as the double doors closed. You could slice the tension in the small space with a butter knife, but in your angry and sleep-deprived state, you really didn’t care. Your father was severely injured and someone was gonna answer for it.

The big guy exhaled sharply through his nose but didn’t look at you or even turn his head in your direction.

“Oh, so it’s gonna be like that, huh?” you challenged, nodding your head bitterly. “I see how it is.”

“Your dad’s safe. That’s all you need to know for now,” he said.

You scoffed. “That’s all I need to know for now? Really?! My dad has had this job for less than a week and he’s laid up in a hospital bed, comatose, covered in burns and—and casts and—what the hell happened to him? Why won’t anyone tell us anything? We deserve to know!”

“Your dad knew what he was signing up for when he took this job,” the man growled, pointing a large finger in your face. You bit your tongue to keep from slapping it away. “It’s not pretty, and you’re in the dark, and you’re pissed. I get it. But there’s a reason you don’t know more right now, and trust me when I say that it’s a damn good one!”

“I seriously doubt when he signed the dotted line that having over half of his body burned within the month was on his mind,” you seethed, venom in every last syllable. “This is complete bullshit!”

Patience and empathy was clearly not one of this man’s strong suits as he pursed his lips and clenched his fists; you even heard a knuckle pop. He didn’t say a word as the elevator doors opened and he strutted down the hall, leaving you fuming behind him.

The car ride was full of silent tension and searing stares. It was at moments like this when you wished you were born with super powers, or were a technical genius, so that you could get the kind of information you wanted. Holding a giant plasma canon in the guy’s face or shooting lasers at him with your eyes would definitely loosen his lips. For now, you’d just have to settle with death glares in the rear view mirror. If he noticed, he didn’t show it. Those stupid sunglasses made it impossible to tell, anyway.

As he pulled up behind the bus lane, you exited the SUV as soon as you possibly could. He yelled something to you but you slammed the door in his face, giving you a faint sense of satisfaction. That’ll show him.

To your shock, Ned and Peter were power-walking toward you. The moment they’d spotted you exiting the noticeable black vehicle in the sea of yellow buses, they weaved through the crowd of high school students. You’d only known the guys for a few days and they were approaching you with such concern in their eyes that you didn’t know what to think.

“Hey, Y/N!” Ned yelled as he came closer, waving as if you couldn’t see them in the crowd. “Y/N!”

You couldn’t help but smile slightly, shaking your head. Ned had a painstakingly clueless air about him sometimes.

“Hey, guys,” you sighed as they stopped in front of you. You tried to grin but the effort made your face hurt so you quickly abandoned the idea.

“Are you okay? What happened?” Peter asked, such genuine concern in his brown eyes and endless kindness in his voice. You felt your shoulders relax.

“Yeah, what happened? You look awful,” Ned said.

You glared and raised your hands questioningly. Peter’s head turned toward Ned slowly, his expression incredulous.

“Gee, thanks, Ned,” you scowled.

The reality of what he’d said seemed to set in on him, and Ned’s mouth formed an 'O’.

“I—I didn’t mean that you don’t look good,” Ned said quickly. “I mean, you’re like the hottest girl in school right now anyway, right, Peter?”

Your stare morphed from a glare to confusion, and you looked to Peter. He suddenly seemed intensely uncomfortable. Ned looked at Peter for support, raising his eyebrows, begging for his friend to help him out of the hole he’d dug.

“Uh, I mean, you—you always look g-good… great,” Peter gulped, glaring at Ned and meeting your eyes anxiously.

“Always,” Ned added enthusiastically, nodding at you over Peter’s shoulder.

You huffed out a weak laugh. Ned looked relieved and Peter looked like he wanted to melt into a puddle. “Nice save, guys.”

The bell rang and you turned toward the front doors, following the large crowd of your classmates. You assumed that Ned and Peter were right behind you, but when you turned to talk to them, you discovered that they were a few feet back, Peter whispering furiously at Ned. You grinned to yourself, thinking of Peter’s flustered compliments. A single butterfly flapped its wings inside your stomach, and you savored the feeling—something other than fury and hopelessness was a refreshing and welcome change.

The wolf whistles that followed you down the hallway that morning went in one ear and out the other. Your mind was floating through the hospital and into the room with your father. Your hands shook as you opened your locker, unable to twist the correct combination until your third try. Before the lock finally gave, you were about to start crying.

“Hey, do you need any help with your books?” came a soft voice beside you, and the frustrated tears threatening to spill retreated at the sound.

“No, it’s okay, Peter,” you said, stuffing two binders into your backpack and putting three books into your locker. “I’m just a little… distracted, is all.”

“I get it,” he said, swinging his backpack over one shoulder. “If—if you want to talk about it, I’ve been told I’m a good listener. Me and Ned. We’re good listeners.”

You smiled but it didn’t reach your eyes, an all-too-familiar ache returning to the middle of your throat.

“Um, maybe at lunch. It’s kind of a long story.”

“Sure,” Peter nodded, eager to accommodate. You turned to walk toward homeroom and Peter stayed by your side, talking about the next machine that he and Ned were building for their class later in the day. It was obvious that he was doing his best to make conversation and keep your mind off of whatever was bothering you, and you were thankful. As far as you could tell, Peter was a total saint.

He stopped at the classroom door, suddenly self-conscious. He reached to scratch at the back of his neck, and the movement caught your eye.

“Sorry, you probably don’t even care about robotics,” he apologized, almost embarrassed.

“No it’s okay—”

“Most people don’t.”

“Oh, Peter, anything you say is a thousand times better than what’s going on in my head right now,” you smiled, touched. It did reach your eyes this time, and your throat ached for a different reason. You lightly brushed his arm before hooking your thumbs back under you backpack straps.

Peter Parker could read the phone book to you and you’d listen with rapt attention.

He glanced at his forearm where you’d touched him, and then up to your eyes. They were so chocolate. There was a mix of relief and something else swimming in them, and whatever the something else was, it added a butterfly or two to the dancing colony in your stomach.

Peter seemed to catch himself. He pointed behind him. “I—I need to go. I’ve already been late to English twice this week.”

You grinned. Now that you thought about it, Peter was almost late wherever he went.

“See you at lunch, Parker.” The corner of your lips pulled up.

“Yeah,” he nodded, backing away but still facing you, “yeah. Okay, bye.”

Your hands didn’t leave your backpack straps but you stretched out your fingers and wiggled them as a farewell. He smiled—then proceeded to back into someone and almost make them drop their books.

You snorted to yourself as he exclaimed “Sorry!” at the unsuspecting guy and sprinted away down the hall.

Ned made small talk with you in homeroom, and you could tell that he was doing his best to distract you just like Peter was. There must’ve been something about your face that revealed the turmoil tossing and turning beneath.

Lunch was a blessing. By the time the bell rang and freed you, the frustration and need to vent were so strong that you were about to burst. Ned and Peter were smart guys and longtime New-Yorkers with plenty of experience in the alien invasion department. Surely they’d have some idea of what was going on.

You were the last to sit down at what had become your friend group’s designated table. Ned and Peter were in a deep discussion that cut off the second you were within earshot. You tried not to be bothered by the fact that they always seemed to be changing subjects around you—after all, they’d been best friends for years and they barely knew you. But it bugged you nonetheless.

“So, you promised us a juicy story at lunch today,” Ned reminded you, tone light and teasing. You’d much rather his nonchalant approach than anyone treating you like a cracking china doll.

You sighed and picked up your plastic fork, prodding what was supposed to be spaghetti on your plate. With your stay in the hospital, packing lunch hadn’t been an option.

“Where do I even start?” you exhaled, dropping the fork and pushing the plate away. You’d suddenly lost your appetite, not that you had much of one in the first place. “With the bulletproof SUV? Or what about the bodyguard that constantly has a stick shoved up his ass?”

“What?” Peter asked, clearly confused.

You rubbed your eyes and colorful stars appeared in the corners of your vision. “It’s my dad. There was some kind of accident at his office and he’s in the hospital.”

“Oh, that sucks,” Ned breathed. “I’m so sorry.”

“What happened?” Peter asked, his brows pulled together.

“I don’t even know,” you chuckled hopelessly. “They won’t tell us anything. All the doctor will say is, 'we’re keeping an eye on him’. Every time I ask someone a question I get looked at like I’m about to have a nervous breakdown or get shot, one of the two.”

“Y/N… what exactly does your dad do?” Peter inquired, leaning forward slightly.

“It’s a government job,” you explained. “I think the official term for his division is Alien Affairs or something. I don’t even know what he does. I don’t think I’m supposed to.”

Something in Peter’s body language changed. Ned’s eyes snapped to him before landing back on you.

“The bodyguard makes sense then…” Ned muttered, almost to himself.

“And get this,” you continued, the weight of holding all of your frustrations inside beginning to lift, “the place is like a prison. No one goes in or out without armed supervision, even family. And the floors above and below where government employees are kept are empty, for 'security reasons’, they said. What the hell does that even mean?”

“Why would they be guarding a hospital if there was just an 'accident’?” Ned wondered.

“Because it probably wasn’t an accident,” Peter replied, looking at one spot on the table. You could practically hear the whir of wheels turning inside of his brain.

“What—what do you mean it wasn’t an accident?” you blanched, trying to catch his eye, but his were still glued to the table.

He finally met your prodding gaze and suddenly seemed a little nervous, like he had a time limit to get all of the words out. “I mean, y-you know, Mr. Stark deals with the government all the time. He says they lie more than they tell the truth. Everything is, uh, always covered up until they’re sure they aren’t liable for anything.”

You shrugged and rolled your eyes at the accuracy. “Sounds about right.”

“Did they at least mention when he’d be released?” Ned asked.

You shook your head and looked at your lap, fighting back the stinging at the corner of your eyes. “No. But it won’t be anytime soon. You should’ve seen him… he looks burned.”

“Do you think there was a fire or something?” Ned asked.

“Or maybe it’s chemical burns. I don’t know,” you sighed. “It’s the not knowing that’s the worst.”

Peter had gone quiet, and you found yourself biting the inside of your cheek. Was he awkward around talk of grief? Maybe he was uncomfortable. But no, something told you, he’s thinking. Thinking hard.

“What is it, Peter?” you asked, your voice a mixture of hope and caution. What if he said something that you didn’t want to hear?

He suddenly bolted out of his seat, his chair tumbling to the floor with a loud clatter. He was grabbing his things and stuffing them into his backpack. His mind was obviously somewhere that wasn’t the cafeteria.

He was leaving. Again.

“Dude, where are you going?” Ned questioned, but whether it was for his benefit or yours, you didn’t know.

Peter was backing away, making to run, looking right at you. “It’s Mr. Stark, I forgot about—about that thing. Cover for me in Chemistry, Y/N?”

“Uh—”

But he was gone in a flash of chocolate hair and a bouncing backpack.

trail.content_abstract:
“The Man Behind the Mask”

Pt 4

Peter Parker x reader

Warnings: Hospital, description of injured family member

Summary: You’ve recently moved to Queens, New York after your father finds a new job with the U.S. government handling alien affairs in the city. You’ve grown up in a small town, and it’s your junior year of high school; culture shock takes a whole new meaning when you’re saved by the famed new web-slinging Avenger - and when you meet a new group of friends at Midtown High that seem to always be hiding something. But things quickly get personal.

Masterlist / Pt 1 – Pt 2 – Pt 3

It was a blur of sounds and lights and faces. The black car your mother had taken to the school was a company car – a government car. With a driver. It all seemed so cold and official. Your mom was crying beside you in the backseat but unsuccessfully trying to hide it, for your sake. She tried to explain through her sobs what happened at your father’s workplace, but it seemed that she didn’t really know many details at all. Everything government-related was secretive, especially when it concerned alien affairs, and especially when the word ‘accident’ was thrown around. You were sure that they were keeping you and your mother in the dark about what happened – you’d bet money that they always knew more than they were saying.

The man in the suit and sunglasses behind the wheel never said a word and his facial expression never changed throughout the drive to the hospital. He seemed entirely uninviting. You noticed a bulge at his side underneath his suit jacket, and it didn’t take more than a moment to realize that it was a gun. Of course it was. What was he, security detail? To keep you and your mother safe or to maybe keep you two from probing more than you should be into the incident? Either way, you found his presence completely unnecessary and a bit unnerving.

Pulling up to the hospital, you threw open the SUV door before the vehicle was completely stopped and ran toward the doors despite your mother’s protests. The lobby was cold and sterile, bringing chill bumps to your arms. Your sense of foreboding only heightened.

“Baby, don’t go running off like that,” you heard your mother beg from behind you, resting her shaking hands on your shoulders. “I know that you want to see your dad, and—and that this is scary, but we’ve gotta stick together.”
